column1: This section provides a comprehensive glossary of all variables
column3: and shocks used in the two-country New Keynesian DSGE model. The home economy is the United States (US)
column4: and the foreign economy is China (CN).

column1: Aggregate consumption in the United States and China
column2: respectively. Consumption is defined as a CES composite of domestically produced and imported goods.

column1: Consumption of home (US) and foreign (China) goods by US households.
Consumption of US and Chinese goods by Chinese households.
Labor supply in the US and China. Labor is supplied competitively by households and demanded by firms.
Aggregate output (national production) in the US and China.
Output of an individual firm producing differentiated goods in the US and China.
Natural (flexible-price) level of output in each economy.

column2: defined as deviations of actual output from natural output.

column1: Prices of domestically produced and imported goods in the US.
Prices of US and Chinese goods in China.
Inflation rates in the US and China
column2: defined as log changes in the CPI.

column1: Nominal wages in the US and China.
Real marginal costs faced by firms in the US and China.
Nominal policy interest rate set by the Federal Reserve.
Nominal policy interest rate set by the People’s Bank of China.

column2: defined as the relative price of foreign goods to home goods.
defined as the price of foreign currency in terms of domestic currency.

column1: Stochastic discount factors in the US and China.
Nominal bond holdings of households in the US and China.
Degree of financial dollarization in China
column2: representing the share of financial assets or liabilities denominated in foreign currency.

column1: Productivity shocks in the US and China
De-dollarization (or dollarization) shock affecting China’s financial system.
Coefficient of relative risk aversion and inverse of the intertemporal elasticity of substitution.
Inverse Frisch elasticity of labor supply.

column2: representing the probability that firms cannot adjust prices.

column1: Elasticity of substitution among differentiated goods.
Slope of the New Keynesian Phillips Curve
column2: determining inflation responsiveness to marginal costs.
measuring the share of imported goods in consumption.

column1: Elasticity of substitution between domestic and foreign goods.
Composite parameter capturing trade-related spillovers in the IS equation.
Interest rate smoothing parameters for the US and China.
Monetary policy response coefficients to inflation.
Monetary policy response coefficients to the output gap.
Spillover coefficient capturing China’s response to US interest rate movements.
Sensitivity of China’s monetary policy to dollarization pressures.
Response of dollarization to domestic inflation in China.
The model combines standard New Keynesian mechanisms with international spillovers and a novel dollarization channel. Dollarization weakens monetary policy transmission in China
column2: requiring stronger policy responses and generating cross-border effects that influence US monetary conditions
